pros: Interview process Friendly knowledgeable individuals Collaborative environment
cons: There is a lot to learn but training has been great so far.

pros: The starting pay and the company's intention of changing healthcare.
cons: The pay is not worth your health. This company does not know how to act as a team. PTO is not yours and you are expected to answer calls and emails. The managers are horrible and are allowed to bully employees. The CEO and his team are very out of touch with the entire company. It wasn't like this in the beginning but that's where they landed. They spend tens of thousands of dollars on off-site leader retreats that happen multiple times a year but don't have enough money to give bonuses that were announced to the entire company during all-hands meetings. This ship is sinking. Please don't leave a good job to drink their Kool aid. You will regret it.

pros: Great pay and benefits, remote working and fellow employees are great. IT is one of the best I have seen in rapidly resolving issues.
cons: Lack of leadership. Hired with no training and little follow up from leadership. Top down leadership is not setting the pace for the company. Very fragmented leadership.

pros: Most people are nice Decent pay Nice in office environment
cons: If you're looking for an opportunity to work hard and climb the ladder, don't come here. You go through about 5 interviews and then told the position has been frozen due to financial restrictions. AKA we would like a better applicant pool because why interview people if you don't have the funds to hire for that position? Ohh, so they also assume your stupid as well. Some departments are legit like working with people who never matured from high school, super cliquey, like love the smell of each others farts and if you disagree with them on anything, looooook out. There's also this whole act like they want to help foster careers. So you start in one position, and they say we value you and anything we can do to help you grow, lets chat......but then when you want to shadow people in other departments or see another side of the model, so that you can potentially "GROW"..........."no sorry we don't have coverage to do that." A LOT OF TALK, LITTLE TO NO ACTION. Oh and if you apply to multiple jobs internally, you're told by HR that they don't take your application seriously because you've applied to 2 or 3 positions that you think you could be great at. That's when I knew it was time to get out. So beware! All the people that put in the real work like nurses, service coordinators, doctors, clinical educators, system educators, IT folks, and people in Engagement are really nice. Everyone else is a bunch of fake bureaucratic sycophants that stroke each others egos.

pros: Changing lives! Great people! Great work space!
Fake PTO; do no respect your time off
cons: The leadership is beyond lack luster and is horrible at transparency. They hold on to low performers and try to cut salary’s without laying you off. They have more lay offs, pivoting targets than any start up.

job_title: Clinical Services Coordinator in Boston, MA
pros: Good Salary Good Company Work life balance Hybrid Great management

review_title: Great pay but horrible at keeping employees
job_title: Clinical Services Coordinator in Boston, MA
pros: Great pay, collaborative environment, frequent office events
cons: Not willing to work with employees, Horrible work life balance, False sense of flexibility, Unwillingness to teach employees how to limit mistakes and grow

pros: Tele work, remote, hospital at home
cons: Lack of policies, understaffed, many technology platforms

review_title: Great business model, room for better execution
pros: Great business model and truly hire people passionate about helping others. Pretty good benefits and unlimited PTO.
cons: Questionable/little leadership. Slow with annual reviews, raises, and promotions.

pros: Pay, remote options, coworkers, NPs are nice
They give you money and unlimited PTO just like every other start up.
cons: No work life balance, they expect everything of you and be available 24/7/365 despite their unlimited PTO option. They prop up employees with little-to-no leadership abilities or clinical expertise. Their senior leadership are excellent as gaslighting and faking a facade of community and collaboration. They claim to be a tech company yet have the worst tech product.

pros: Upper Management is really good at talking bs
cons:
Often employees are ones getting the bs.
Something about the place feels sketchy.
Flaky Management 
No loyalty- I saw 3 people fired just bc they “weren’t a good fit”
A large portion of the job can be done by unskilled person. 
No collaboration. Very secretive, lots of nepotism 
Nursing opinions were never heard often in situations where patient safety was in question.
Did I mention something felt sketchy?

pros: Leadership leads with passion and morality.
cons: Normal startup issues like on-boarding and not enough employees.

pros: Uncapped PTO, good office culture, great coworkers
cons: Lack of training and long days
